thread.title: IMF warns of lower living standards and calls for reform
thread.title_full: IMF warns of lower living standards and calls for reform | afr.com

author: Alan Mitchell
title: IMF warns of lower living standards and calls for reform
text:
The IMF's annual report on Australia says the economy's "outperformance" is fading, with the potential growth rate expected to slow in the years ahead. by Alan Mitchell The International Monetary Fund has downgraded its outlook for Australia's medium-term growth and warns that the federal and state governments' current efforts to return the budget to surplus is having an excessively negative impact on the economy.
The IMF's annual report on Australia says the economy's "outperformance" is fading, with the potential growth rate expected to slow in the years ahead.
The IMF's growth projections show the economy staging a moderate cyclical recovery in the next two years, but slowing to an annual growth rate of 2.8 per cent by the end of the decade.
Living standards, as measured by real net per capita national disposable income, are projected to continue falling next year and still be below their 2013 level at the end of the decade.
Use GST for tax cuts The IMF urges the Australian federal and state governments to push ahead with economic reform to boost productivity.
"There are few low-hanging fruit, but a range of reforms have been identified," it says.
"Addressing infrastructure needs would relieve bottlenecks and housing supply constraints.
 "The tax system should shift towards more efficient taxes, while ensuring fairness, including by preventing personal income tax bracket creep and reducing the corporate tax rate, paid for by higher GST revenue – while compensating those on lower incomes.
The fund puts its weight behind a costly increase in bank capital ratios which, it says, "need to be increased substantially to ensure banks are 'unquestionably' strong".
The IMF staff report says that the Australian economy's overall vulnerabilities are low, describing house prices as only moderately overpriced.
However, it says the risks to economic activity are skewed to the downside and could interact to "exacerbate the impact on the economy".
The main disagreement with government policy is on the question of fiscal policy.
"The sizeable output gap and the large structural transition of the economy call for supportive aggregate demand policies," it says.
However, "fiscal policy is imparting a substantial negative impulse".
The fiscal tightening by the states and the Commonwealth, it estimates, will see cyclically adjusted balances improve by a combined 0.75 per cent of gross domestic product on average over the next three years.
"A small surplus should remain a longer-term anchor of fiscal policy," it says.
"But [IMF] staff assesses the planned consolidation as somewhat more front-loaded than desirable.
"Boosting public investment would support demand, take the pressure off monetary policy, and insure against downside growth risks. This would need careful co-ordination between different levels of government and broader federal support."
Housing hard landing On the risks confronting the economy, the IMF warns that non-resource demand could be slower to pick up than expected, and further terms of trade falls could entrench slower growth, higher unemployment and fiscal deficits, especially if there is reform inertia.
At the same time, it says, the housing market could experience a hard landing .
"Current efforts to rein in riskier property lending might not be sufficiently effective. Against a backdrop of already high house prices and household debt, this could give rise to price overshooting and excessive risk-taking," the IMF warns.
"A sharp correction in house prices, possibly driven by Sydney, could be triggered by external conditions – for example, a sharper slowdown in China or a rise in global risk premia.
"The house price cycle could be amplified by leveraged investors looking to exit the market and a turning commercial property cycle."
The IMF warns that investors in self-managed superannuation funds that have added geared property to their fund portfolios would also be among those adversely affected in a downturn.
